title: Latest Ohio news, sports, business and entertainment at 9:20 p.m. EDT
summary:
WASHINGTON (AP) — The U.S. and global economies have come to a shuddering stop, unleashing a wave of layoffs that is much larger and moving much faster than job losses in previous downturns.
They are swamping state unemployment benefits systems and leaving many Americans still working anxious about whether they will be next.
Tens of thousands of laid-off workers have already flooded state unemployment websites across the country to apply for jobless benefits.
In the week ending March 14, the number of people seeking unemployment aid soared by 70,000 to 281,000, the Labor Department said Thursday.
And many states are already reporting big increases in benefit applications this week, which weren't included in those figures.

title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Business Executives Call for More Testing; Trump’s W.H.O. Attack Is Condemned
summary:
On a call with Trump about reopening, business executives call for more testing.
When the first conference call of President Trump’s economic advisory council on reopening the economy was held Wednesday morning, several business executives echoed a cry that health officials and state and local leaders have been making for weeks, according to two participants: The country needs more testing.
There appeared to be a wide consensus that more virus testing was needed to track who was infected and who might have immunity before employees could return to work.
Workers who felt that they were brought back too soon or were not placed in an adequately safe environment could sue en masse.
Asked about their call for more tests — after the slow rollout of testing hampered the nation’s ability to identify the outbreak and combat it — Mr. Trump said Wednesday evening that he agreed.

title: Columbus sets high-temperature record for date on Saturday
summary:
Columbus more closely resembled a rainy Memorial Day weekend than a midwinter freeze on Saturday.
The high temperature of 71 degrees, reached at 2:02 p.m., broke the record for the date of 66 degrees set 130 years ago, on Jan 11, 1890, according to the National Weather Service.
That followed Friday’s record-setting low of 45 degrees at John Glenn Columbus International Airport.
It was the highest low temperature for the date on record, exceeding the 43 degrees in Columbus on Jan. 10, 1960.
Central Ohio’s weather roller coaster was expected to take another twist overnight, with temperatures expected to plummet into the 30s, and highs today expected to be only in the 40s.

title: Construction projects poised to transform central Ohio this year
summary:
Work is underway on several development projects that are poised to transform the central Ohio landscape for years to come.
Among the highlights: a new soccer stadium, a new look for the North Market and a new front door for Ohio State University.
Work will begin this year on a new stadium, a new look for the North Market and dozens of other developments that will continue the transformation of central Ohio.
Despite the surge of construction in the past few years, experts say this year could be the most significant yet.
For now, these 10 projects underway this year are poised to reshape the central Ohio landscape for years to come.

title: Women’s March not happening in Columbus
summary:
There will be no pink hats, pro-choice posters or megaphone-powered speeches in the streets of Columbus, Ohio, during the Women’s March Saturday.
Rhiannon Childs, former executive director of the Ohio Women’s March, said she didn’t expect the march to turn into an annual event.
According to previous Lantern reporting, more than 700 activists attended the 2019 Ohio Women’s March in Columbus.
“I don’t think people understand how much work it is.”According to the Women’s March website, there are nine marches happening in Ohio Saturday, with the closest to Columbus being in Westerville.
As far as the Women’s March not happening in Columbus, Childs said she isn’t too pressed about it, and others shouldn’t be, either.

title: Spring in January? Record Breaking Warmth Saturday
summary:
Spring-like trend Friday and Saturday across the Ohio valley with temperatures well above average highs.
A major storm system pulls warm, tropical air as far north as the Ohio valley with strong southerly wind.
And with that stronger southerly flow temperatures jump into the 60s and low 70s for some in Ohio.
Warm enough to break 130 year old records for some major cities in the Buckeye state!
Cities like Dayton, Columbus and Cincinnati most likely will have new record high temperatures.

title: Buyers pushed up prices in central Ohio’s affordable neighborhoods in 2019
summary:
Prices jumped by double-digit percentages in Whitehall, Driving Park and other lower-cost communities in 2019 as homebuyers, priced out of expensive neighborhoods, looked for homes they could afford.
In those and other lower-cost communities, prices jumped in the double-digit percentages as buyers, priced out of expensive neighborhoods, looked for homes they could afford.
The median sales price of a Whitehall home jumped 16.7% from 2018 to 2019, following a 14.9% bump in 2018.
According to Zillow, home values in the East Side neighborhood of Driving Park jumped 29% last year, the largest increase of any Columbus neighborhood Zillow tracks.
In Driving Park and other urban neighborhoods, flocks of home flippers are helping spike prices.

title: Despite violent start to year, Columbus leaders optimistic homicide rates will continue downward trend
summary:
COLUMBUS, Ohio (WCMH) — Despite a violent start to 2020, Columbus city leaders say they’re optimistic homicide rates will continue on a downward trend.
She said the city is pouring resources into public outreach, neighborhood canvassing following violent crimes, and better access to resources.
She credits declining yearly homicide totals to such collaborations as the Violent Crime Review group, saying eight different city departments spent last year knocking on more than 1,600 doors after violent incidents.
“Now that we feel like we have a good foundation in that area, now as time goes on I think we’re going to see a reduction in the violent crime,” she said.
“We need to do better with those who are involved in violence and help them so they can reduce that violent behavior and we don’t lose lives,” she said.

A university spokesman said foul play is not suspected in the death of Corey Ray Bias, 20, of Johnstown.
Columbus fire crews were called to the site near Neil and West 11th avenues around 6:30 a.m., according to 911 calls obtained by The Columbus Dispatch.

title: What better time to leave than at end of Ohio State’s 150th and strongest year, Drake says
summary:
During his remarks before the University Senate at the Ohio Union, Drake ticked off several points of university progress and advancement over the past several years.
Among Ohio State’s improvements is increased need-based financial aid for students and families, Drake said.
A smaller share of Ohio State students now graduate with debt, down from 55% percent five years ago to 50% today, Drake said.
“What better time to transition than at the completion of our university’s 150th and strongest year ever?” Drake asked.
“It was important to us that Ohio State be accelerating on a path forward and be well-positioned for success.”Still, Ohio State is not without challenges, Drake said, referencing mental health on campus.

title: Columbus, central Ohio to be hit by wind, cold blast; watch for refreeze
summary:
Northern Ohio received 2 to 5 inches of snow, while we had ice overnight Friday.
Winds are gusting around 40 mph over western Ohio, so expect a period of strong winds overnight, subsiding to 20-25 mph Sunday morning.
This will drop the wind chill to near zero at times, as cold as we’ve seen (comparable to Nov. 12).
Lake-effect snow flurries will be prevalent with the frigid weather Sunday and Monday, especially with the lakes unfrozen at a record late date in January.
High pressure will build in through the early part of the week, with crisp sunshine.

title: Rascal Flatts says 2020 tour will be its last, no Columbus date set
summary:
Country music trio Rascal Flatts said Tuesday morning that an upcoming tour beginning in June will be its last.
Marking the band's 20th anniversary, the Rascal Flatts Farewell: Life Is a Highway Tour kicks off June 11 in Indianapolis and concludes Oct. 17 in West Palm Beach, Fla.
The band, which has roots in central Ohio, has not announced a concert date in Columbus as part of the farewell tour.
The group last performed in Columbus during the 2017 Ohio State Fair.
Tickets for the farewell tour will be available first as part of the Live Nation Country Megaticket.

title: One dead, 3 injured in southwest Columbus crash
summary:
COLUMBUS (WCMH) — One person was killed and several others were injured in a crash in southwest Columbus.
A passenger in the Chevrolet, Mary Stolzenburg, 66, of Columbus, was taken to Doctor’s Hospital where she later died from her injuries.
Two other passengers in the Chevrolet were injured in the crash.
The driver and a passenger in the Ford Ranger were taken to Grant Medical Center in stable condition.
Columbus police continue to investigate the crash.

title: Police identify man killed in shooting near south Columbus bar
summary:
COLUMBUS (WCMH) — Police are investigating a shooting in south Columbus that left a man dead.
According to the Columbus Division of Police, at about 1:42am, Saturday, officers were called to a sports bar in the 3500 block of Parsons Avenue on the report of a shooting in the parking lot.
When officers arrived on scene, they found Joseph Edward Fisher, 27, lying on the ground suffering from a gunshot wound.
According to police, there is a person of interest in the shooting and they are working to locate and interview the individual.
Police ask anyone with information on the shooting to call the CPD Homicide Unit at 614-645-4730 or Central Ohio Crime Stoppers at 614-461-8477.

title: Wexner’s central Ohio legacy extends far beyond L Brands
summary:
From New Albany fields to Wexner Medical Center operating rooms, Leslie H. Wexner has left his mark on central Ohio.
Leslie H. Wexner’s impact on central Ohio can be felt from the fields of New Albany to the operating rooms of Ohio State University’s Wexner Medical Center.
Wexner’s impact on central Ohio can be felt in other, more subtle, ways.
While the effects of Wexner’s philanthropic ventures can be felt throughout central Ohio, his business ventures have likewise left a permanent imprint.
Starting with L Brands’ Morse Road headquarters, Wexner shifted the axis of central Ohio to the east.

title: Body found on Columbus west side
summary:
FRANKLIN TOWNSHIP, Ohio (WCMH) — A decomposed man’s body has been found on the west side of Columbus, according to the Franklin County Sheriff’s Office.
A sheriff’s office spokesman said a Franklin Township officer responded to a call for a body found off Lincoln Park Court at approximately 11 a.m. Thursday.
The officer confirmed the body was male.
The sheriff’s office spokesman said that due to the severity of the decomposition, the cause of death or how long the body has been there are currently unknown.
Detectives are still on the scene investigating.

Ohio State University police are investigating after a third-year student was found dead at a construction site on campus Friday morning, but officials said foul play is not suspected.

title: Police investigating after male’s body found in east Columbus

title: Mild & Wet pattern lingers into mid-January - WBNS-10TV Columbus, Ohio | Columbus News, Weather & Sports
summary:
This week has been off to a relatively mild start and we actually have a colder than average day ahead on Wednesday.
The jet stream is the force driving our weather pattern and it's been spending much of it's time up north.
It looks similar to the previous jet stream forecast for this upcoming Friday and based on this, it looks like this jet stream pattern will be lingering into the 3rd week of January.
By this I mean the flow in the jet stream will be more zonal or west to east.
Jet Stream forecast for Wednesday 1/15Not only that, but we could also start to see the jet stream shift a little further south, which would allow for cooler conditions during the latter half of the month.

title: Central Ohio housing market showing strains because of coronavirus
summary:
The central Ohio housing market remained robust in February, but signs are increasingly pointing to buyers and sellers now staying put because of the coronavirus outbreak.
Figures released Friday show that the central Ohio housing market remained robust through February, but evidence mounted this week that the coronavirus outbreak is crushing that market along with the rest of the economy.
Columbus-area home sales jumped 13% to record highs and prices rose 6.7% in February compared with a year earlier.
The numbers for March are likely to look very different, as potential buyers and sellers stay put during the pandemic.

title: February home sales jump to highest in over a decade, but big drop expected as coronavirus injects uncertainty
summary:
The spring housing market was on its way to becoming the strongest in over a decade, but it will likely turn sharply lower, as the economy shuts down in the face of the coronavirus.
The market is still plagued by low supply, which worsened in February.The inventory of homes for sale fell 9.8% annually to 1.47 million.
Low supply pushed the median home price in February up 8% annually to $270,100.
The upper end of the market saw the biggest sales growth – the lower end saw the biggest drop, because supply is leanest on the low end.
Given how strong housing demand has been, some are not convinced of a major collapse in the housing market.

title: Sunday, 02/02/2020, is a rare palindrome day across the globe - WBNS-10TV Columbus, Ohio | Columbus News, Weather & Sports
summary:
TAMPA, Fla. (WTSP) — Sunday is a big day: it’s the Super Bowl, Groundhog Day and it’s the first palindromic date of the year.
That means February 2, 2020 can be written the same way forward and backward.
It will be 02/02/2020 all over the world, and that hardly happens because not every country writes the dates the same format.
According to USA Today, the last time this happened was 909 years ago on November 11,1111.
If you go with the mm-dd-yyyy format, there are only 12 palindrome days in the entire 21st century.

The virus has infected more than 218,000 people worldwide and killed over 8,800, mostly in China, Italy and Iran.
More than 84,000 people overall have recovered from the virus, which causes only mild or moderate symptoms such as fever and cough in most cases.

title: Trump says feds developing new guidelines for virus risk
summary:

He has been trying for days to determine how to contain the economic fallout of the guidelines issued by his administration as well as local leaders to slow the tide of infections.
Last week Trump unveiled a 15-day program advising against large gatherings and calling for many Americans to remain at home.
On a conference call with governors Thursday, Trump stressed the need to reopen businesses and to recognize regional differences in the virus’ impact.
The announcement of the forthcoming new guidelines comes days after Trump said he hoped to “reopen” the country by Easter.

Just as grocery stores have been stripped bare by Americans panicked by coronavirus, guns and ammunition have started flying off the shelves.
“It's been insane,” said Jay Wallace, who owns Adventure Outdoors in Smyrna, Georgia, adding that his ammunition sales are up more than five times the usual numbers.
Gun sales generally rise in an election year, as they did in 2016.

title: Ohio on track to lose jobs in 2019
summary:
The state’s employers cut 1,000 jobs in October, and Ohio now has 10,300 fewer jobs than it did in January, according to Ohio Department of Job and Family Services data released Friday.
Unless something changes, and fast, 2019 will be the first year that Ohio has shed jobs since 2009, when the state lost nearly 200,000 during the Great Recession.
Government employment increased by 3,000, driven by a gain of 3,100 local government jobs and 700 state government jobs.
The leisure and hospitality sector added 2,400 jobs last month, and the sector that covers private education and health care added 2,300 jobs.
A broad sector of jobs that covers fields such as dry-cleaning, laundry services and pet care cut 2,300 jobs during the month.

Some things even went into the backpack that hung from the back of her scooter, the one that partially obscured her U.S. Air Force sticker.
Last year, only 8% of the veterans who attended Stand Down were women.
And then she learned from Project Healing Water Fly Fishing that volunteers will take veterans fishing for free.

title: Job growth in manufacturing stalls in Ohio
summary:
Employment growth in manufacturing has stalled, according to state data released Friday that shows Ohio has lost 2,200 manufacturing jobs over the past year.
After years of mostly steady gains since the Great Recession, job creation in manufacturing has stalled in Ohio.
Although the state added 100 manufacturing jobs last month, the sector has given up 2,200 in the past year, according to Ohio Department of Job and Family Services data released Friday.
Even with fewer jobs, manufacturing represents a big part of the Ohio economy.
The leisure and hospitality sector added 2,200 jobs, and the private education and health care sector added 1,300.

title: 'Armed & dangerous' suspect wanted after 20-year-old shot to death in southeast Columbus
summary:
COLUMBUS, Ohio — Columbus police are searching for a suspect in the shooting death of a 20-year-old man in southeast Columbus.
Ahpercy Lee Rayion Wade Donaldson was found suffering from a gunshot wound in a parking lot by responding officers.
Donaldson was taken to Mount Carmel East in life-threatening condition where he was later pronounced dead.
Police say he is armed and dangerous and should not be confronted.
Anyone with information on the shooting or suspect is asked to call the Columbus Police Homicide Unit at 614-645-4730 or Central Ohio Crime Stoppers at 614-461-TIPS.

title: Job creation in Ohio gained steam at the end of 2019
summary:
After mostly treading water in 2019, Ohio turned in its best months for job creation in November and December.
Still, job creation over the past year was the slowest in Ohio since the end of the Great Recession.
Job creation picked up in the last two months of 2019 in Ohio, turning in the best numbers in a year in a state that mostly treaded water last year.
The 2019 growth rate of 0.5% was 38th in the country, compared to a 1.4% growth rate for the U.S., Ayers said.
While job creation was slow, the state’s labor force increased by a robust 81,000 people from December 2018 to December 2019.

title: Ohio family faces uncertainty as 2 sons, husband diagnosed with rare genetic disorder
summary:
Nathan Anderson and two of his four sons, Griffin, 10, and Brennan, 4, have been diagnosed with a rare mutation on their Runx1 gene.
Wife and mother, Joy Anderson, has become an outspoken advocate for the condition — and her family.
Typically, that’s acute myeloid leukemia, which is most common in adults over 60, but the Runx1 mutation increases the risk for AML in all ages.
Earlier this year, Joy Anderson was the first patient family representative to speak at the organization’s annual conference.
She’s become very active in increasing awareness of the Runx1 mutation, which is underdiagnosed, Ericson said.

title: DeWine drops 'red-flag' law, mandatory universal background checks from gun plan
summary:
Mike DeWine was not backing off his insistence that a “red flag” law and universal background checks would be part of his bid to reduce gun violence.
The legislation DeWine proposed Monday also walked back an earlier proposal to require universal background checks on all gun sales — including private sales and those at gun shows.
Ohioans want common-sense gun safety.
More than 90 percent of Ohioans want more common-sense gun safety, not watered-down proposals to appease the gun lobby," she said.
Dennis Willard, spokesman for Ohioans for Gun Safety, said the group will continue to collect signatures to put universal background checks on the November 2020 ballot.

title: Two nights before debate, five Democratic candidates descend on Ohio
summary:
Almost exactly 48 hours before Democrats take the stage in Westerville for the next presidential primary debate, five of the candidates made their case before more than 1,000 at the Ohio Democratic Party's annual state dinner Downtown.
The three front-runners didn't show up, but the five Democratic presidential candidates who did appear Sunday night got an enthusiastic reception from more than 1,000 Ohioans at the party's annual state dinner at the Greater Columbus Convention Center.
Instead, they directed their fire at President Donald Trump, with several saying any of the Democratic candidates would make a better president than the GOP incumbent.
Speaking, in order, were South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg, Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar, Youngstown-area Congressman Tim Ryan and businessmen Tom Steyer and Andrew Yang.
"I want to be the president who can bring people together," he said, espousing a goal that when people see President Buttigieg on TV, their blood pressure will go down, not up.

title: Ohio drops 6,300 jobs in January; 12,500 positions lost over past year
summary:
"These are kind of backward indicators," Bill Adams, a PNC Bank economist, said of the state jobs report.
Ohio’s job data for January showed cuts in several sectors, led by a drop of 8,600 government jobs, including 7,600 state jobs.
The professional and business services sector lost 6,900 jobs; the next biggest losses were 1,700 in manufacturing and 1,600 in finance.
The sector of private education and health care added 5,200 jobs, and the leisure and hospitality sector added 4,300.
Over the past year, government employment fell by 12,200, led by a loss of 8,500 state jobs.

title: Polish artist's works fly over Columbus
summary:
Nearly three dozen suspension sculptures designed by Polish artist Jerzy Jotka Kedziora will be on display in three Columbus parks and at the Main Library.
The pieces will be on display in three Columbus parks — Schiller, Livingston and Thurber — and at the Main Library from Sunday until March 1.
The exhibit is presented by the Friends of Schiller Park in association with the Art & Balance Foundation of Poland.
Friends of Schiller Park spent $10,000 to transport the works and the crew to install it.
Two sculptures placed at Schiller Park, "Man-Bell" and "Woman-Bell," pay homage to Polish revolutionaries during the country's rejection of communism.

title: Columbus Italian Festival marks 40 years
summary:
Taking place Friday through Sunday in the heart of Italian Village on the streets near the St. John the Baptist Italian Catholic Church, the festival celebrates that nation's food and culture.
Unlike most parishes, St. John the Baptist Italian Catholic Church isn’t subject to geographic boundaries.
Since 1898, the church has served the Italian community throughout Columbus.
The festival eventually relocated in 1999 to the grounds of St. John the Baptist, where it now regularly attracts 35,000 visitors during its three-day run.
A third generation Italian American, 71-year-old Pat Rossetti has been on various festival committees since the second year.

All classes and school activities were canceled Tuesday due to the extreme heat and lack of air conditioning in some of the school buildings.
The District will require all essential employees to report for work.

All four people were taken to the hospital.

title: The year 2019 was fraught with scandal, rough on farmers

title: Ohio Medicaid still “hemorrhaging” money to pharmacy middlemen, expert testifies
summary:
A national drug-pricing consultant says that despite implementing a new pricing system and other efforts to rein in pharmacy middlemen, Ohio’s Medicaid program continues "hemorrhaging" tax dollars.
"You are hemorrhaging money right now," Linda Cahn, a critic of pharmacy benefit managers, or PBMs, told the Joint Medicaid Oversight Commission on Thursday.
PBMs hired to oversee the $3 billion-a-year drug program have contracts that allow them to increase profits rather than keeping costs down, she said.
Cahn said that to solve the problem, the state needs to negotiate an "air-tight contract" or handle pharmacy benefits in house.
The $28 billion Medicaid program provides health insurance to nearly 3 million poor and disabled Ohioans.

title: Ohio on track to lose jobs in 2019
summary:
The state’s employers cut 1,000 jobs in October, and Ohio now has 10,300 fewer jobs than it did in January, according to Ohio Department of Job and Family Services data released Friday.
Unless something changes, and fast, 2019 will be the first year that Ohio has shed jobs since 2009, when the state lost nearly 200,000 during the Great Recession.
Government employment increased by 3,000, driven by a gain of 3,100 local government jobs and 700 state government jobs.
The leisure and hospitality sector added 2,400 jobs last month, and the sector that covers private education and health care added 2,300 jobs.
A broad sector of jobs that covers fields such as dry-cleaning, laundry services and pet care cut 2,300 jobs during the month.

The upgrade will happen after the ice rink closes for the season and be completed by the time it would normally reopen next year, said Alicia Shoults, spokeswoman for the Expo Center.
During the winter months, the Coliseum is a relief valve for organizations that are competing for limited ice time at rinks around central Ohio, Shoults said.

title: Job creation in Ohio gained steam at the end of 2019
summary:
After mostly treading water in 2019, Ohio turned in its best months for job creation in November and December.

title: Job growth in manufacturing stalls in Ohio
summary:
Employment growth in manufacturing has stalled, according to state data released Friday that shows Ohio has lost 2,200 manufacturing jobs over the past year.
After years of mostly steady gains since the Great Recession, job creation in manufacturing has stalled in Ohio.
Although the state added 100 manufacturing jobs last month, the sector has given up 2,200 in the past year, according to Ohio Department of Job and Family Services data released Friday.
Even with fewer jobs, manufacturing represents a big part of the Ohio economy.
The leisure and hospitality sector added 2,200 jobs, and the private education and health care sector added 1,300.

title: JACK Casino Cleveland overtakes Hollywood Columbus as Ohio’s busiest casino for November
summary:
CLEVELAND, Ohio - While MGM Northfield Park in November maintained its lead as Ohio’s busiest racino, JACK Casino Cleveland overtook Hollywood Columbus as the busiest casino in a month for the first time in more than three years, reports released this week by the state show.
Gambling revenue - the money kept by the house after paying out winnings - totaled $18.8 million in November at the Cleveland casino, edging above Hollywood Columbus with its $18.6 million in revenue.
For the entire year, however, the Columbus casino has a wide lead, $209.6 million to $192.9 million over Cleveland.
Ohio’s top table game facility again was Cleveland, with $9.2 million of the $23.1 million of table gaming revenue statewide.

title: Franklin County Children Services levy passes easily
summary:
Voters extended their longstanding record of support for Franklin County Children Services, easily approving a 3.1-mill renewal levy that officials say is crucial for maintaining services.
Officials say the crisis has pushed more children into the care of county children service agencies and left them with needs that are more complex, both physically and emotionally.
Because the levy is a renewal of an existing 10-year tax, property owners will not see their tax bill increase.
More than two-thirds of Children Services operating funds come from two 10-year levies, with the 3.1-mill renewal accounting for about 42% of the agency's income.
Children Services aided more than 32,000 children and their families in 2018 and had more than 4,700 kids in agency custody by the end of that year.

title: Ohio on track to lose jobs in 2019
summary:
The state’s employers cut 1,000 jobs in October, and Ohio now has 10,300 fewer jobs than it did in January, according to Ohio Department of Job and Family Services data released Friday.
Unless something changes, and fast, 2019 will be the first year that Ohio has shed jobs since 2009, when the state lost nearly 200,000 during the Great Recession.
Government employment increased by 3,000, driven by a gain of 3,100 local government jobs and 700 state government jobs.
The leisure and hospitality sector added 2,400 jobs last month, and the sector that covers private education and health care added 2,300 jobs.
A broad sector of jobs that covers fields such as dry-cleaning, laundry services and pet care cut 2,300 jobs during the month.

title: Job creation in Ohio gained steam at the end of 2019
summary:
After mostly treading water in 2019, Ohio turned in its best months for job creation in November and December.
Still, job creation over the past year was the slowest in Ohio since the end of the Great Recession.
Job creation picked up in the last two months of 2019 in Ohio, turning in the best numbers in a year in a state that mostly treaded water last year.
The 2019 growth rate of 0.5% was 38th in the country, compared to a 1.4% growth rate for the U.S., Ayers said.
While job creation was slow, the state’s labor force increased by a robust 81,000 people from December 2018 to December 2019.

title: Job growth in manufacturing stalls in Ohio
summary:
Employment growth in manufacturing has stalled, according to state data released Friday that shows Ohio has lost 2,200 manufacturing jobs over the past year.
After years of mostly steady gains since the Great Recession, job creation in manufacturing has stalled in Ohio.
Although the state added 100 manufacturing jobs last month, the sector has given up 2,200 in the past year, according to Ohio Department of Job and Family Services data released Friday.
Even with fewer jobs, manufacturing represents a big part of the Ohio economy.
The leisure and hospitality sector added 2,200 jobs, and the private education and health care sector added 1,300.

title: Neighbors given OK to return home after no ‘nuclear reactor’ or hazards found at Northwest Side home
summary:
A Northwest side man will undergo a mental-health evaluation after his 911 call Thursday night led emergency responders to evacuate his entire street over concerns about a possible small nuclear reactor and potential radiation in his garage, a fire official said.
Battalion Chief Steve Martin, the Columbus Fire Division’s media spokesman, said the man’s description of the device suggested he was working on a small nuclear reactor and included references to a particle accelerator and alpha waves.
Radiation level checks were conducted on the man and then at the residence and nothing was found, Martin said.
A nuclear specialist brought to the scene found in the garage what was identified as a homemade capacitor, Martin said.
After it was determined there was no threat, residents were allowed to return to their homes at 9:20 p.m.

Police and fire medics were originally called just before 2 p.m. Monday after a number of people called about shots fired at Hardesty Village, a townhouse-style apartment-condo complex off Eakin Road near Whitethorne Avenue.
A male later identified as McGill fired multiple shots at responding police from a broken-out window on the second floor of his townhouse-style residence in a building at the rear of the complex, police said.
Griffith said the man will be charged with felonious assault on police officers for firing multiple shots at them with a long rifle.
A Columbus City school bus delivered Alan Herdman and other students about 5:30 p.m. to the Forest Creek complex.

title: Wolf’s Ridge, Ohio State, educate aspiring beer makers on the brewery process
summary:
Wolf’s Ridge and Ohio State’s microbiology department held a symposium on the beer-making process on campus and at the Downtown brewery Friday.
The Ohio State lab teamed up with Wolf’s Ridge Brewing in Columbus for a one-day course on the basics of making sour beer.
The course was titled “Sour Symposium II,” and served as a more in-depth version of the first Sour Symposium, a two-hour workshop that took place over the summer.
McFeely said he recently signed a lease on a Downtown space near Wolf’s Ridge that he plans to transform into a brewery.
Byron Williams, 53, of Hilliard, said Wolf’s Ridge is one of his favorite breweries and he attends many of their events.

title: Hilltop teen charged with delinquency murder after man shot to death in vehicle on Near East Side
summary:
The early morning shooting is the city’s 104th homicide of 2019, passing 2018’s tally.
The 17-year-old suspect was shot multiple times himself on the Hilltop last month.
A Hilltop teenager was arrested early Sunday morning in connection with the shooting death of a 26-year-old man on the Near East Side.
Keyontay Perry, 17, who lives on the Hilltop, was arrested and charged with a delinquency count of murder, according to the release.
Police said the reason for the Sunday morning shooting is still under investigation.

title: Blue Jackets snap skid, end Capitals' winning streak at six
summary:
WASHINGTON (AP) — Because the Washington Capitals don't lose very often, they'll try to take something from a letdown game against the Columbus Blue Jackets rather than just burning the video.
The Capitals' seven-game point streak came to an end two days before facing the Boston Bruins in a showdown of the league's top two teams.
“Maybe that will loosen him up and allow him to play.” Blue Jackets coach John Tortorella said.
... Blue Jackets F Emil Bemstrom returned to Columbus to see doctors about an upper-body injury suffered Saturday at Florida.

summary:
Below, you’ll find our roundup of the significant urban development projects that were under construction throughout the year.
The first tenants are scheduled to move in to The Hayden in early 2020, while work continues on a second historic renovation a few blocks away.
An 18-unit building is being built in a parking lot that sits behind an existing High Street building.

title: Santa’s Wonderland debuts at Cabela’s featuring FREE photos with Santa
summary:
Santa’s Wonderland is the ultimate free family Christmas event returning to Cabela’s this holiday season.
Columbus-area families are invited to enjoy this enchanting Christmas village offering FREE 4×6 studio-quality photos with Santa and free family holiday activities including fun crafts and games.
Guests can reserve their free visit and photo with Santa using the free Bass Pass system.
Visit the Bass Pass Ticket Depot located at the entrance of Santa’s Wonderland to pick up a time-stamped pass.
(OR, for digital passes) Guests can register online for a digital Bass Pass to see Santa, allowing them time to explore Santa’s Wonderland or shop while they wait.

title: Central Ohio All Star Preps: ThisWeek banquet now is one-night showcase
summary:
For the last two years, there have been separate fall and spring (winter and spring athletes) banquets.
This year, there will be one banquet, the Central Ohio All Star Preps event, and we will be inviting more than 300 athletes and 29 coaches from the ThisWeek coverage area.
“I’m honored to be part of the first All Star Preps for Central Ohio,” Shazier said.
“Since arriving in central Ohio 15 years ago, we have grown to 17 area community restaurants.
The announcement for winter honorees will be in April and the one for spring athletes will be in May.

title: Ohio family faces uncertainty as 2 sons, husband diagnosed with rare genetic disorder
summary:
Nathan Anderson and two of his four sons, Griffin, 10, and Brennan, 4, have been diagnosed with a rare mutation on their Runx1 gene.
Wife and mother, Joy Anderson, has become an outspoken advocate for the condition — and her family.
Typically, that’s acute myeloid leukemia, which is most common in adults over 60, but the Runx1 mutation increases the risk for AML in all ages.
Earlier this year, Joy Anderson was the first patient family representative to speak at the organization’s annual conference.
She’s become very active in increasing awareness of the Runx1 mutation, which is underdiagnosed, Ericson said.

title: Columbus police, victims’ families ask for help ending gun violence
summary:
Family members of four homicide victims joined with Columbus police Monday to encourage the community to come forward with information to help solve cases and work to reduce violent crime.
Becker said the felony gun crime investigation unit is increased its staffing to handle its large caseload.
Some 755 felonious assaults were reported in Columbus in 2018, and 740 had been reported in 2019 as of Thursday.
The level of violence, while relatively small compared to the city’s population, should offend everyone in Columbus, Becker said.
Tips or information can be provided anonymously on any homicide case by calling Central Ohio Crime Stoppers at 614-461-TIPS.

title: Tower gardens teach central Ohio students about crops, conservation
authors: Alissa Widman Neese The Columbus Dispatch
summary:
Thanks to a partnership with Mount Carmel Health System and area health departments, students in nine central Ohio school districts are growing crops using vertical tower gardens in their classrooms.
Thoughtful ideas also sprouted, as they discussed ways to conserve the planet’s limited resources, including the land that humans use to grow food.
Tower gardens are generally low maintenance, requiring only routine water monitoring and cleaning.
In addition to Reynoldsburg, Canal Winchester, Whitehall and South-Western schools are some districts that also have tower gardens.
That includes fish raised through aquaculture farming and crops grown in vertical gardens, similar to the ones that students started using this year but on a larger scale.

title: Male killed in South Linden shooting
summary:
Columbus homicide detectives are investigating after a male was fatally shot on a South Linden street.
Police and fire medics responded around 9:30 p.m. to a shooting in the street toward the west end of the 800 block of East 13th Avenue, west of Cleveland Avenue where 13th dead-ends into the I-71 noise wall and across the interstate from the Ohio Expo Center.
Paramedics reported that the male was in trauma arrest and they were transporting him to Ohio State University’s Wexner Medical Center.
He was pronounced dead at Wexner at 9:53 p.m., police said.
The unidentified male is the 99th homicide victim in the city for 2019No other details about the shooting were immediately available late Thursday night as investigators were still on the scene.

title: Have fatal overdoses kept falling in Ohio in 2019? Not likely, counties say
summary:
County coroners say Ohio is unlikely to see another large drop in drug deaths in 2019 to rival the precipitous decline seen in 2018.
Fatal drug overdoses fell more than 22% last year in Ohio, the first bright spot in years in an epidemic that has ravaged the state.
But as county coroners tally drug deaths so far for 2019, they are not predicting a repeat of such good news.
Stark, Summit and Scioto counties are among the 17 of Ohio's 88 counties reporting that they had met or surpassed 2018 overdose death numbers already this year.
For years, Ohio had among the highest fatal drug overdose rate in the nation.

title: Teen dead, two others injured in Easton-area crash
summary:
A 16-year-old girl died and two other people were injured as the result of a two-vehicle crash on the Northeast Side early Monday morning.
The crash was reported just after 2 a.m. on Sunbury Road, south of Morse Road.
According to Columbus police, a 2007 Chevrolet Aveo was headed north on Sunbury when it crossed the centerline into southbound traffic.
One occupant of the Aveo was killed, and two others were injured in the crash.
Shrissa Holmes, 16, of North Linden, was taken to Mount Carmel East hospital, where she died about 20 minutes later.

title: Yard art or trash? Family cleans up Geno Centofanti’s legacy
summary:
Robert Geno Centofanti, whose Morse Road house was an irritant for neighbors and the city because of his front yard art that was trash to some, has died.
Robert Geno Centofanti had butted heads with Columbus officials and his neighbors for more than two decades over what he called "yard art" and others called trash and junk that he had accumulated over the years.
He said items like a rusted bird cage enclosing a tree stump were yard art.
Over the years, Centofanti’s yard art included pallets, furniture, used car parts, a rubber rat attached to a table and a concrete goose with a television for a head.
Centofanti didn’t fight it.

title: Overnight snow making roads slick for Monday commute
summary:
Central Ohio motorists could encounter tricky road conditions Monday morning after some snow fell overnight.
Fairfield and Pickaway counties were both under Level 1 snow emergencies early Monday, meaning roads were icy.
Similar snow emergencies were issued for much of southeastern Ohio.
School districts in southeastern Ohio delayed the start of classes, and some, including Fairfield Union and New Lexington schools, closed for the day.
The National Weather Service office in Wilmington has issued a winter weather advisory starting at 4 p.m. and continuing until 10 a.m. Tuesday.

title: Ohio attorney featured in ‘Dark Waters’ movie continues legal battle against forever chemicals
summary:
Robert Bilott, an Ohio attorney who took on DuPont for contaminating water with toxic forever chemicals, is portrayed by Mark Ruffalo in "Dark Waters," which hits theaters in central Ohio on Dec. 5.
The last frames of the movie “Dark Waters” are set in a federal courtroom in Columbus.
Bilott’s court battle is chronicled in “Dark Waters,” which opens Thursday in theaters throughout central Ohio.
A website, Truth About Dark Waters, touts jobs created by manufacturing in the Ohio River Valley and lists critical reviews of the movie.
Dark Waters is no exception.

title: Coronavirus timeline: How the coronavirus spread from cases in China to Ohio in less than three months
summary:
CLEVELAND, Ohio – The coronavirus grew from a few cases in Wuhan, China, to a pandemic with cases in Ohio in what seems like less than three months.
Dec. 31, 2019 – China reported a cluster of pneumonia cases associated with the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market in Wuhan, Hubei Province.
And the first coronavirus death occurs outside of China in the Philippines.
Feb. 11 - WHO names new coronavirus COVID-19, intentionally avoiding including a place name to prevent inaccuracy or stigma.
March 10 – DeWine issues recommendations on coronavirus spread.

title: Woman in critical condition after being hit in northwest Columbus
summary:
COLUMBUS (WCMH) — A woman was taken to a local hospital in critical condition after being hit by a car Friday afternoon.
According to Columbus Police, the victim was struck near Olentangy River Road and Jasonway Avenue at approximately 4:20 p.m.
The woman was taken to Riverside Hospital in critical condition.
Olentangy River Road is closed near West Henderson Road as police investigate the scene.
The southbound exit from Olentangy River Road to Route 315 is also closed.
